title: Benjamin Learning Wheel
description: An interactive wheel exploring Walter Benjamin's key concepts, artist types, examples, and reflection prompts.

segments.concept_blurb: Unique presence tied to time/place; challenged and reimagined in the age of copies.

slices.label: Sacred Originals — "Art as relic, glowing with presence."
slices.prompt: When does a work feel sacred to you—and why?

slices.label: Mass Multiples — "Copy it, sell it, flood the world."
slices.prompt: What happens to value when images are endlessly repeatable?

slices.label: New Auras — "Performance, pixels, and screens reinvent presence."
slices.prompt: Can a livestream or performance create its own kind of aura?

segments.concept_blurb: Printing, photography, film, and digital spread multiply images and change reception.

slices.label: Access for All — "Everyone gets a copy, no gatekeepers."
slices.prompt: Does easier access deepen understanding—or just make images cheaper?

slices.label: Market Spectacle — "Repetition as brand, spectacle as sales pitch."
slices.prompt: When does multiplication become pure marketing?

segments.concept_blurb: Cameras reveal patterns and details the unaided eye misses.

slices.label: Machine Vision — "The lens reveals what eyes can't."
slices.prompt: What realities appear only through slow motion, zoom, or high resolution?

slices.label: Painter's Eye — "Only the trained gaze claims authority."
slices.prompt: What can embodied looking do that machines can't?

segments.concept_blurb: Progress looks like a storm blowing us into a pile of ruins; art can witness both loss and drive.

slices.label: Ruins and Wreckage — "The past piles up in shards."
slices.prompt: Where do you see cultural ruins in everyday life?

slices.label: Forward Storm — "Progress is a hurricane blowing us onward."
slices.prompt: What gets sacrificed when we chase the new?

slices.label: Witnessing Both — "Between loss and hope, the artist stands."
slices.prompt: How can art hold grief and possibility at once?

segments.concept_blurb: Art is never neutral; it can resist, retreat, or turn politics into product.

slices.label: Revolutionary — "Art as weapon, banner, uprising."
slices.prompt: When does art function like a rally cry rather than a picture?

slices.label: Escapist — "Beauty as refuge, art as retreat."
slices.prompt: Is withdrawal from politics its own political stance?

slices.label: Commodifier — "Politics as product, controversy as currency."
slices.prompt: When does provocation feel engineered for sales rather than thought?

credits.framework: Inspired by Walter Benjamin's concepts: aura, mechanical reproduction, optical unconscious, angel of history, and art's political stakes.
